posts.cooked:
Our team is planning to use the REV magnetic limit switch on our elevator. The design team’s plan is to use a single sensor with multiple magnets placed at different points on the elevator. The goal is for the elevator to move to a specified position when a button is pressed, stopping at the correct magnet for that level. For example, if I press the L4 button, the elevator should pass two magnets before stopping at the third.

I’m not sure how to approach this. If anyone has experience with a similar setup or any ideas, I’d really appreciate your insight.

(Sorry if the explanation is unclear—I was given a brief rundown of the concept.)

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
If you are using brushless motors with encoders built-in, I’d encourage you to use the encoders for positioning and limit switches to set the encoder absolute reference.

(If you’ve considered and discarded this idea, that’s fine; I just want to ensure you’ve considered it as that’s probably easier.)

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: The best way to do this is probably by counting the number of magnets that pass by the sensor, but I would recommend doing what sokoloff suggested above. A limit switch is typically designed to have a binary output, which means it won’t give you a good idea of how far away you are from your desired position. This situation is probably better suited by an absolute encoder, specifically an absolute encoder because it won’t lose its position between power cycles.
I have thought about using encoders for this, however I don’t really know how to use them or how to go about to use them.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I like the advice herein to use the limit switches at the ends (that’s what limit means) and the encoder in between. A typical industrial solution is switches line the fixed part and one magnetic moves up and down.

Be sure to debounce the switches if they don’t already have that feature.

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked: The problem with elevators is they want to fall down and a brake of some kind is needed to hold them up while an action happens. That is normally done by closing a position loop around an encoder. Otherwise you will need a mechanical brake of some kind.

So we have decided to count the magnets the sensor passes for the elevator.

I don’t have a real idea how to approach that in code. I have a idea how it should work but not really in code. Any help for that would be helpful.

Here is the code I have quickly made (haven’t tested) and think might be a start.

And I also looked for some resources for encoders and couldn’t really find any, if anyone has anything that would also be

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Fundamentally, encoders do just count the number of magnets that pass by. Just with much, much more counts per rotation, along with some other improvements. So the process is more or less the same.

Let’s start with counting your magnets, as a concept. When the robot boots up, you have to make some sort of assertion about where you are. Likely, this is the bottom of the robot, but you kind of need to make absolutely sure by running the motor downward (gently please). After some amount of time, you can say “yup, bottom” and start counting from zero.

As you go up, you hit an encoder and say “1!”, and do your thing. And then you go down again, and say “0!”. But here’s the problem: Your magnet can’t tell you if you hit it going up or if you hit it going down . So you don’t know whether to add or subtract. For big motions, this is fine (you can roughly say by the motor power), but if you’re parked at/near the motor, and your system goes up and down a little, you’ll lose track. This is generally known as “bouncing”, and it causes you to lose track of stuff like this.

So, the solution is to add additional data here, such as a second magnet, offset from the first so they trip at different points in the motion on a different digital input. Now magnet A can go on and off all it wants, but magnet B was never triggered, so you can confidently say “I’m still at magnet A”. Once magnet B is triggered, you can say “OK, now I’m going down”. The order in which you hit them provides additional clues to your location and travel direction

And, now you’ve reinvented encoders, which do exactly this, generating this pattern.

Codewise, you’re using a Spark, so it’s really easy: You can just ask the built in encoder for it’s position using m_Elevator.getEncoder().getPosition() . You can look at how far off you are, and do something sensible about it. By default, the Spark relative encoder counts number of rotations of the motor to ~3 decimals of precision.

This code is a good starter base for it.

This is a very, very rudimentary closed loop control system: This is a “proportional” closed loop, which is the P in PID (which you’ve probably seen and heard of).

Of course, the numbers here are somewhat nonsensical, as I don’t know what your system looks like. But, seeing the math and what you want out of it ( # encoder ticks * some random value -> output between -1 and 1 ), you can get a rough guess for what kP should be.

As before though: You still boot up the robot and it has no idea where this encoder actually is . So, you may want to do the same routine: Go to the bottom (gently), and then say “I’m at zero!” which you can do with a command that runs m_Elevator.getEncoder().setPosition(0) on completion.

Once you have this basic type of structure, you’re well set up to start doing more advanced closed loop control and adding precision over time. Good places to branch into afterward include

Rate limiting the setpoint changes (helps prevent mechanical wear and noise)

Adding simple feedforward values (kG will be the easiest and most fruitful)

Improved closed loop tuning (sometimes just fiddling with numbers)

Eventually, trapezoidal profiles (which provide extremely good control, but require a bit of research from where you’re at)
